title: Past Perfect
description: Слушайте и определяйте предшествующее действие в прошлом.

tasks.audioText: When I arrived at the airport, the plane had already departed. I had to wait for the next flight.
tasks.transcript: When I arrived at the airport, the plane had already departed.

options.text: The plane left before I got to the airport.
The plane was leaving when I arrived.
I arrived before the plane departed.
The plane and I arrived at the same time.

tasks.explanation: 'Had already departed' shows the plane left before the arrival — Past Perfect marks the earlier action.

tasks.audioText: She was very confident during the interview. She had prepared for weeks before the meeting.
tasks.transcript: She had prepared for weeks before the meeting.

options.text: She prepared during the meeting.
She spent weeks getting ready before the interview.
She will prepare for the meeting next week.
She was preparing while the meeting was happening.

tasks.explanation: 'Had prepared' indicates preparation happened over weeks prior to the interview — a completed action before another past event.

tasks.audioText: By the time the ambulance arrived, the neighbours had already called the doctor twice.
tasks.transcript: The neighbours had already called the doctor twice.

options.text: The neighbours called after the ambulance came.
The neighbours were calling the doctor when the ambulance arrived.
The neighbours had contacted the doctor two times before the ambulance got there.
The neighbours never called anyone.

tasks.explanation: 'Had already called twice' means the calls happened before the ambulance arrived — Past Perfect for an earlier completed action.

tasks.audioText: Tom couldn't log into his account. He had forgotten his password after changing it the day before.
tasks.transcript: He had forgotten his password after changing it the day before.

options.text: He forgot the new password he had set the previous day.
He changed his password and remembered it.
He was forgetting his password at that moment.
He will forget his password tomorrow.

tasks.explanation: 'Had forgotten' shows the forgetting happened before the attempt to log in — the password change was even earlier.

tasks.audioText: We were starving by noon. We had not eaten anything since the previous evening.
tasks.transcript: We had not eaten anything since the previous evening.

options.text: We ate a big breakfast that morning.
We were eating lunch at noon.
We hadn't had any food from the evening before until that point.
We decided not to eat the next day.

tasks.explanation: 'Had not eaten since the previous evening' uses Past Perfect negative to describe a state lasting from before until the reference point.

tasks.audioText: The students looked relieved when the results came out. They had studied extremely hard for the final exams.
tasks.transcript: They had studied extremely hard for the final exams.

options.text: They studied hard after seeing the results.
They put a lot of effort into studying before the exams took place.
They were studying when the results arrived.
They will study hard for next year's exams.

tasks.explanation: 'Had studied' indicates the intense studying happened before the results came out — Past Perfect for the earlier event.

tasks.audioText: Maria was surprised to see her old friend at the conference. They had not seen each other for over ten years.
tasks.transcript: They had not seen each other for over ten years.

options.text: They met regularly every year.
They will not see each other for ten years.
Their last meeting was more than a decade ago.
They were seeing each other frequently at conferences.

tasks.explanation: 'Had not seen for over ten years' uses Past Perfect negative to describe a long period without contact before the conference meeting.

tasks.audioText: The project manager was frustrated on Monday morning. The team had missed the deadline by two full days.
tasks.transcript: The team had missed the deadline by two full days.

options.text: The team finished the project two days early.
The team failed to deliver on time and was two days late.
The team is going to miss the deadline soon.
The manager missed the deadline himself.

tasks.explanation: 'Had missed the deadline' uses Past Perfect to show the deadline failure happened before Monday morning.

tasks.audioText: I couldn't find my car in the parking lot. Someone had moved it to a different spot while I was at work.
tasks.transcript: Someone had moved it to a different spot while I was at work.

options.text: I moved the car myself before work.
Someone relocated my car during my working hours.
Nobody touched the car all day.
Someone will move the car tomorrow.

tasks.explanation: 'Had moved' shows that the car was relocated before the speaker returned — a completed prior action.

tasks.audioText: The restaurant was closed when we got there. The chef had left early because of a family emergency.
tasks.transcript: The chef had left early because of a family emergency.

options.text: The chef left after we arrived at the restaurant.
The chef was still cooking when we got there.
The chef departed before we arrived due to a personal situation.
The chef will leave early next week.

tasks.explanation: 'Had left early' indicates the chef's departure happened before their arrival — Past Perfect for the earlier event with a reason.

tasks.audioText: Laura felt nervous on her first day abroad. She had never travelled outside her home country before.
tasks.transcript: She had never travelled outside her home country before.

options.text: She had been abroad many times.
It was her first time being in a foreign country.
She travels abroad every summer.
She was travelling at that exact moment.

tasks.explanation: 'Had never travelled before' uses Past Perfect negative with 'never' to express a first-time experience up to that point in the past.

tasks.audioText: The police questioned the suspect for hours. He had been at the scene but claimed he had seen nothing unusual.
tasks.transcript: He had been at the scene but claimed he had seen nothing unusual.

options.text: He was present at the location but said he did not notice anything strange.
He was not at the scene at all.
He saw many unusual things and reported them.
He will go to the scene later today.

tasks.explanation: 'Had been' and 'had seen nothing' use Past Perfect twice to describe states and actions before the police questioning.

tasks.audioText: James was exhausted after the marathon. He had trained for six months without taking a single day off.
tasks.transcript: He had trained for six months without taking a single day off.

options.text: He trained for six months with many rest days.
He will begin training for the marathon next month.
He spent half a year training every single day before the race.
He stopped training after two months.

tasks.explanation: 'Had trained for six months without a day off' uses Past Perfect to show continuous preparation before the marathon.

tasks.audioText: The software crashed during the presentation. Nobody had tested the latest update before the demo.
tasks.transcript: Nobody had tested the latest update before the demo.

options.text: Everyone tested the update thoroughly.
The update was tested during the demo.
No one checked the newest version before showing it to the audience.
The software worked perfectly at the presentation.

tasks.explanation: 'Nobody had tested' uses Past Perfect negative to explain that testing did not happen before the demo — the cause of the crash.

tasks.audioText: My grandfather told wonderful stories about places he had visited during his years as a sailor.
tasks.transcript: He had visited many places during his years as a sailor.

options.text: He is visiting places now as a sailor.
He went to numerous locations when he worked as a sailor in the past.
He had never been anywhere as a sailor.
He plans to visit many places in the future.

tasks.explanation: 'Had visited' uses Past Perfect to describe experiences that occurred during an even earlier period — his sailing years before the storytelling.

short_description: Предшествующее действие в прошлом: had + V3.
